Antonio Estache The reforms have been remarkable for their speed and innovation-despite the complexity of the issues and the lack of "off-the-shelf" models to follow at the time. The overall result has been positive. Many services have improved. Traffic has grown-up about 180 million passenger trips a year. Subsidies have been cut dramatically-down from US$2 billion or so a year to a little more than US$100 million. But as with any complex reform, there is an unfinished agenda. And with the Argentine approach becoming a model for other countries in Latin America, this review of the lessons starting to emerge from the reform experience is a timely one.
